choices.A: Change the organization name on both controllers to match viptela.com.
choices.C: Reconfigure the system IPs to belong to the same subnet.
choices.D: Remove the encapsulation ipsec command under the tunnel interface of vBond.
choices.B: Configure the encapsulation ipsec command under the tunnel interface on vManage.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Answer is A

https://community.cisco.com/t5/sd-wan-and-cloud-networking/encapsulation-ipsec-on-vbond/td-p/4451149
"encapsulation" command under vBond tunnel-interface has no meaning and effect.
Answer A
Answer should A

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. vManage and vBond have an issue establishing a connection with each other. Which action resolves the issue?

choices.A: Configure a valid certificate on vSMART.
choices.C: Configure a valid serial number on the WAN Edge.

discussion.content:
Organization Mismatch (CTORGNMMIS)
Organization Name is a critical component for bring up of the control connection. For a given overlay, the Organization name has to match across all the controllers and vEdges so that control connections can come up.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/routers/sd-wan/214509-troubleshoot-control-connections.html#anc17
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer is getting a CTORGNMMIS error on a controller connection. Which action resolves this issue?

discussion.content:
I have tested this in a lab environment, B looks correct

#RootCA
openssl req -x509 -new -nodes -key ROOTCA.key -sha256 -days 2000 -subj "/C=UK/ST=Hampshire/L=Southampton/O=LAB-1/CN=roger.local" -out ROOTCA.pem

This is from this lab: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X0yfM45sTyk&list=PLplGU0K93TA4oi8wcWGUUtdyJP9VNZ5Ce&index=6

in doc this is an exmaple:

OpenSSL> x509 -req -days 730 -in vmanage.csr -CA subca.crt -CAkey subca.key -set_serial 02 -out vmanage.crt

which options matches this one?

Correct Answer is B
According to Cisco's published guides!

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/routers/sd-wan/215103-how-to-generate-self-signed-web-certific.html#:~:text=vmanage%3A~%2Fweb%24%20openssl%20genrsa%20-out%20rootca.key%202048%20Generating%20RSA,is%2065537%20%280x10001%29%20vmanage%3A~%2Fweb%24%20ls%20rootca.key%20web_cert.csr%20vmanage%3A~%2Fweb%24

comments.content:
B is correct. Step1 says - " generate RootCA Certificate" which matches with command syntax/attributes.
In option A - the comand generates a "vmanage.crt" which is something else. (It will be needed later on)

discussion.content: A is the correct answer
B is correct

comments.content: There's no requirement for cert to be valid for 365 days. It may be valid for 2000 days. Also there's change in ORG name in option B. Plus according the reference which Roger95 provided syntax in option B is correct. I'll go with B.

discussion.content:
A is correct:
Eliminate C/D due to using Symantec in step 2 - as per the question, it should be local enterprise CA as used in A/B
The step 1 should specify 365 days, not 2000, so this eliminates B and leaves us with A.
B is wrong
one thing that bodered me was the O value. The question say that the organization is changed, so the O value must change as well, from the old ABC to XYZ (new organization name)
A is correct

B ONLY - see for syntax below:
student@student-vm:~/lolcalCA$ openssl req -x509 -newkey rsa:2048 -keyout myca.key- -out myca.crt - days 3650 -nodes

comments.content: 3650 days is incorrect, also, it will not be generated on a vmanage. B option specified 2000 days, which is incorrect
There's no problem with 2000 days and it's not incorrect.

discussion.content: B is correct.

comments.content: the number of days does not correspond with the cert in question

discussion.content:
B is the correct answer.
the syntax of the command is: openssl req (without the "-")
 and than go to vManage > Administration > §Controller Certificate Authorization > Enterprise Root Certificate

In Releases 17.1 and later, Cisco vManage can act as a Certificate Authority (CA) and can automatically generate and installed signed certificates on vEdge Cloud router. 

Notice the top left corner. VManage Module RootCa

I lean towards A

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/10175812/how-to-generate-a-self-signed-ssl-certificate-using-openssl

comments.content: I stand by B. The syntax is correct, A isn’t. Also, Why would you want a RootCA only valid for 1 year?
Because the cert in question is valid for 365 days, therefore B can't be valid no matter how you look at it

How can B be correct when the validity of the cert it generates is 2000 days and it uses O=XYZ, although the exhibit shows a cert with a validity of 365 day and O=ABC?

In my opinion, A is the right answer.

discussion.content: The correct answer is B, not A. The syntax for OpenSSL is correct and has the right navigation to the enterprise root certificate directory rather than D.
Right answer should be A

Drag and drop the vManage policy configuration procedures from the left onto the correct definitions on the right.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
The order is correct:
Configure topology
Create group of interest
Apply policies to sites and VPNs
Configure traffic rules

questions.question_text: A vEdge platform is sending VRRP advertisement messages every 10 seconds. Which value configures the router back to the default timer?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The VRRP advertisements are encapsulated in IP packets and sent to the IP v4 Multicast address assigned to the VRRP group. The advertisements are sent every second by default; the advertisement interval is configurable.
vrrp default timer is 1 sec

Answer C is correct, this is straight from the documentation:
 
Specify how often the VRRP master sends VRRP advertisement messages. If slave routers miss three consecutive VRRP advertisements, they elect a new master.
Range: 1 through 3600 seconds
Default: 1 second
